quiz.title: AP Physics C: Mechanics
quiz.subtitle: Unit 1, Quiz 5: Advanced Integration in 1D Motion
quiz.subject: Physics

questions.question: An object starts from rest. Its acceleration is given by $a(t) = 12t^2 - 4t$. What is the velocity of the object at $t = 2\text{ s}$?
questions.explanation: $v(t) = \int a(t) \, dt = \int (12t^2 - 4t) \, dt = 4t^3 - 2t^2 + C$. Since the object starts from rest, $v(0)=0 \Rightarrow C=0$. Thus, $v(t) = 4t^3 - 2t^2$. At $t=2$: $v(2) = 4(8) - 2(4) = 32 - 8 = 24\text{ m/s}$.

questions.question: A particle’s velocity is $v(t) = 6t^2 + 2$. If the particle is located at $x = 12$ at $t = 1\text{ s}$, what is its position at $t = 0$?
questions.explanation: $x(t) = \int v(t) \, dt = \int (6t^2 + 2) \, dt = 2t^3 + 2t + C$. Using $x(1)=12$: $2(1)^3 + 2(1) + C = 12 \Rightarrow 2 + 2 + C = 12 \Rightarrow C = 8$. Therefore, $x(0) = 0 + 0 + 8 = 8\text{ m}$.

questions.question: A particle moves with a velocity function $v(t) = 4\sin(2t)$. What is the net displacement of the particle from $t = 0$ to $t = \pi/2$?
The velocity of a car is $v(t) = 3t^2 + 4t$. What is its average velocity between $t = 0$ and $t = 3\text{ s}$?
An object moves with $v(t) = 10 - 5t$. What is the total distance traveled from $t = 0$ to $t = 3\text{ s}$?
questions.explanation: The object stops when $v(t)=0$: $10 - 5t = 0 \Rightarrow t = 2\text{ s}$. Compute displacements separately: $x(0\to2) = \int_0^2 (10-5t) dt = [10t - 2.5t^2]_0^2 = (20 - 10) = 10\text{ m}$. $x(2\to3) = \int_2^3 (10-5t) dt = [10t - 2.5t^2]_2^3 = (30-22.5) - (20-10) = 7.5 - 10 = -2.5\text{ m}$. Total distance = $|10| + |-2.5| = 12.5\text{ m}$.

questions.question: A particle’s velocity is given by $v(t) = \int_0^t (4\tau + 1) d\tau$. What is the acceleration of the particle at any time $t$?
questions.explanation: By the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus, if $v(t) = \int_0^t f(\tau) d\tau$, then $\frac{dv}{dt} = f(t)$. Here, $f(\tau) = 4\tau + 1$, so $a(t) = \frac{dv}{dt} = 4t + 1$.

questions.question: An object has a constant acceleration $a$. If it starts with an initial velocity $v_0$ and initial position $x_0$, which integral correctly gives the position $x(t)$?
options: Both A and C are correct
questions.explanation: Option A: Integrating velocity $v(t) = v_0 + at$ gives $x(t) = \int (v_0 + at) dt = v_0 t + \frac{1}{2}at^2 + x_0$. Option C: Integrating acceleration twice gives the same result: $\iint a \, dt \, dt = \frac{1}{2}at^2 + C_1 t + C_2$, where constants match initial conditions. Therefore, both are valid approaches.

questions.question: The net force on an object is $F(x) = 2x + 3$. Since $F = ma$, the acceleration is $a(x) = \frac{2x+3}{m}$. If $m = 1\text{ kg}$ and the object starts from rest at $x=0$, what is its velocity $v$ as a function of $x$?
questions.explanation: Using $a = v \frac{dv}{dx}$, we have $v \frac{dv}{dx} = 2x + 3$ (since $m=1$). Separate and integrate: $\int v \, dv = \int (2x+3) \, dx \Rightarrow \frac{1}{2}v^2 = x^2 + 3x + C$. With $v=0$ at $x=0$, $C=0$. Thus, $\frac{1}{2}v^2 = x^2 + 3x \Rightarrow v^2 = 2x^2 + 6x \Rightarrow v = \sqrt{2x^2 + 6x}$.

questions.question: A particle moves with velocity $v(t) = V_0 e^{-kt}$. What is the total distance it travels as $t \to \infty$?
questions.explanation: Total distance = $\int_0^{\infty} v(t) \, dt = \int_0^{\infty} V_0 e^{-kt} \, dt = \left[-\frac{V_0}{k} e^{-kt}\right]_0^{\infty} = (0) - \left(-\frac{V_0}{k}\right) = \frac{V_0}{k}$. This is the finite limiting distance as the particle asymptotically approaches rest.

questions.question: A graph of acceleration vs. time is a triangle with a base from $t=0$ to $t=4\text{ s}$ and a peak height of $6\text{ m/s}^2$ at $t=2\text{ s}$. If $v(0) = 0$, what is $v(4)$?
questions.explanation: The change in velocity is the area under the $a$ vs. $t$ curve. The triangular area = $\frac{1}{2} \times \text{base} \times \text{height} = \frac{1}{2} \times 4 \times 6 = 12\text{ m/s}$. Since $v(0)=0$, $v(4) = 0 + 12 = 12\text{ m/s}$.

scoreMessages.90: Excellent mastery! You can handle complex integration scenarios, including exponential decays, graphical integration, and the fundamental theorem of calculus, with precision.
scoreMessages.70: Very strong performance. Review: applying the fundamental theorem to integral-defined velocities, separating variables for $a(v,x)$, and computing infinite integrals for total distance.
scoreMessages.50: Good foundation. Focus on: integrating polynomial and trigonometric accelerations, calculating average velocity via integration, and solving for constants with initial conditions.
scoreMessages.0: Start with core integration skills: $v = \int a \, dt$, $x = \int v \, dt$, and practice evaluating definite integrals for displacement and average values.
